channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: Elza Soares, a samba singer who rose from the favela to stardom and became one of the few Black women singers in Brazil to be featured in films in the '60s and on TV in the ’70s, died at 91. She "sang until the end," a statement on her Instagram page said. https://t.co/aDrKONGWno

Yakei, a female macaque in a nature reserve in Japan, violently overthrew the alpha male of her troop to become its first female leader in the reserve’s 70-year history.
She presides over 677 monkeys, but a messy love triangle could endanger her status. https://t.co/3sRa36vAHP https://t.co/Gooy6RxWJR

Yakei, a female Japanese macaque in a nature reserve in southern Japan, violently overthrew the alpha male of her troop to become its first female leader in the reserve’s 70-year history.
A messy love triangle could endanger her grip on power. https://t.co/MQ7NwcIv3U

Meat Loaf, the singer and actor whose 1977 album “Bat Out of Hell” was one of the best-selling albums of all time, is dead at 74.
In six decades, he sold millions of albums and appeared in movies including “Fight Club” and “The Rocky Horror Picture Show.” https://t.co/fgx9whlfPO
Deep sea explorers have discovered a sprawling coral reef resembling a bed of roses off the coast of Tahiti that appears to be largely unscathed by climate change. https://t.co/wDoMIMqqLy
Breaking News: Meat Loaf, the larger-than-life singer and actor, is dead at 74. His “Bat Out of Hell” was one of the best-selling albums of all time. https://t.co/cOrKZzyqFL https://t.co/gVIdRgbIcg

The Omicron variant was probably in New York City as early as Nov. 21, four days before South African scientists first announced cases of the variant, a new report on wastewater samples suggests. https://t.co/qU4gKllO16

Planning the Holocaust took all of 90 minutes. Eighty years after Nazis at the infamous Wannsee Conference meticulously mapped out the extermination of Jews in Europe, the bureaucratic efficiency of it remains as unnerving as ever. https://t.co/TOQtYEGAyU

Breaking News: The Massachusetts attorney general, Maura Healey, a Democrat, joined the governor’s race. She is the most well-known candidate to enter the race to replace Gov. Charlie Baker, a Republican who is not seeking re-election. https://t.co/KRDh6IOHAB

In Opinion
When Senator Elizabeth Warren called out Elon Musk for not paying his fair share in taxes, he tweeted: “Please don’t call the manager on me, Senator Karen.” She defends her plan to tax billionaires on the Sway podcast. https://t.co/FO9AdwOBcW https://t.co/JLsysK2xeg

Sparks didn’t fly when Zhao Xiaoqing first met Zhao Fei on a blind date. But on their second date, they got stuck in lockdown together.
Now, they're planning to get engaged. https://t.co/jzDP33BvRA https://t.co/SNnjxg1GXP

The Supreme Court on Wednesday refused a request from Donald Trump to block the release of White House records concerning the Jan. 6 riot, meaning there is no legal obstacle to stop the National Archives from providing the records to the Jan. 6 committee. https://t.co/j5ehKs9qjg https://t.co/X2UqNtMaQZ
Breaking News: An Atlanta district attorney asked to convene a grand jury to investigate Donald Trump’s attempts to overturn Georgia’s 2020 election results. https://t.co/dMaZDu9w1K
Breaking News: Ivanka Trump was asked by the Jan. 6 House committee to cooperate with its investigation into the Capitol riot. https://t.co/cihpeuS1Vv https://t.co/UwJ3JzZm8a

The son of the Czech folk singer Hana Horka, who deliberately exposed herself to the coronavirus, said her death should serve as a warning to others who remain unvaccinated. Horka believed naturally acquired immunity would allow a return to normalcy. https://t.co/3VvFHKqgx8

Dozens of theaters and museums in the Netherlands planned to open as hair salons and gyms on Wednesday in protest over a continued nationwide lockdown on arts venues. The Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam is offering beard trims and Van Gogh-inspired nail art. https://t.co/lMaU5VjNwa

Zara Rutherford just became the youngest woman to fly around the world solo. The British and Belgian aviator is 19.
She dodged giant clouds and lightning flashes, crossed frozen, remote lands and was banned from airspaces during the 155-day journey. https://t.co/GR3F7TP4Kp https://t.co/mMvxLHf2vN

Bankers for Donald Trump’s social media start-up told potential investors they would get a call from the former president if they put in at least $100 million. Despite the deal being structured to make a profit, many of Wall Street’s big names passed. https://t.co/rk0sUCTkLd

In Opinion
“The truth is I almost declined to be the inaugural poet,” Amanda Gorman writes in a guest essay. “I was terrified. I was scared of failing my people, my poetry. But I was also terrified on a physical level.” https://t.co/V5wfBP6Ht6

An American Airlines flight to London from Miami turned around about an hour into its journey because of a passenger who refused to follow Covid masking rules, the airline said. https://t.co/Iw93WhlQLE

Gaspard Ulliel, the French actor known for portraying a young Hannibal Lecter and the fashion designer Yves Saint Laurent, died on Wednesday at 37, the day after a skiing accident. His death comes weeks before he was to appear in a Disney+ series. https://t.co/7vYjc0Djl2 https://t.co/XjqPOZdyVL
Breaking News: Most cases of the mysterious “Havana syndrome” are unlikely to have been caused by Russia or another foreign adversary, the CIA found. https://t.co/1vadnmCM2K

In July, 100 new mothers in parts of New York City began receiving up to $1,000 a month through a privately funded program — a test in the fast-growing field of anti-poverty policy known as guaranteed income. https://t.co/XdwIk5QqYj

Novak Djokovic’s refusal to get vaccinated against the coronavirus could exclude him from both the French and U.S. Open tournaments, reflecting a major shift in how public officials approach Covid requirements and potential exemptions. https://t.co/7opnTDtZ4e

The removal of a Theodore Roosevelt statue at the Natural History Museum in Manhattan, which stirred protests as a symbol of colonialism and racism, has begun. It will be sent to his presidential library in North Dakota in a few weeks. https://t.co/QdKcfWEzDG https://t.co/mnqJXYZ3Du
Breaking News: Newly declassified videos show for the first time the botched U.S. drone strike in Kabul that killed 10 Afghan civilians. https://t.co/CM7eyge0IS

Florida’s top public health official in Orlando, Dr. Raul Pino, was placed on administrative leave after sending an email to his employees urging vaccination against the coronavirus. State law bans Covid vaccine mandates, including for government workers. https://t.co/lh5F1wH72u

The Supreme Court refused a request from Donald Trump to block the release of White House records concerning the Jan. 6 Capitol riot, meaning there is no legal obstacle to prevent the National Archives from providing the records to the Jan. 6 committee. https://t.co/Bf9AJW5Whz https://t.co/FOoPEFIhSB
Breaking News: The Supreme Court refused a request from Donald Trump to block the release of White House records concerning the Jan. 6 Capitol riot. https://t.co/8tnYTjqMyl

“We had been driving for four hours and had yet to see another soul. No people. No cars. Just eerie, lunar nothingness stretching south to the horizon.”
See Genna Martin’s photos of Namibia’s Skeleton Coast, a region often called the end of the Earth. https://t.co/bZJV721zj6 https://t.co/eTbpT9znlD

Kathy Griffin, seeking a career rebirth since a Trump joke gone wrong in 2017, is asking who among the canceled gets a second chance and says she wants to "get back to making people laugh." "More than anything else, that’s what has been robbed from me." https://t.co/Sm2zO6BdvZ

New York’s attorney general said in court papers that Donald Trump’s family business repeatedly engaged in “fraudulent or misleading” practices. The filing was a response to Trump’s effort to block the questioning of him and two of his children under oath. https://t.co/P7leDhjaPI https://t.co/uHeqUixvKY

The Biden administration plans to give out 400 million free N95 masks at health centers and pharmacies across the U.S. Officials called the move, which will be announced Wednesday, the “largest deployment of personal protective equipment in U.S. history.” https://t.co/TI4fz4ZpMK

Weird Al is "absolutely thrilled" that Daniel Radcliffe will be portraying him in an upcoming biopic, saying "I have no doubt whatsoever that this is the role future generations will remember him for." https://t.co/FeTAEdQYae

A lawyer for Britney Spears, in an effort to thwart her father’s demand that she pay his legal bills, claimed in court papers that Jamie Spears and others involved in her conservatorship committed myriad financial improprieties over several years. https://t.co/hQP99PwpRd

"André Leon Talley was a singular force in an industry that he had to fight to be recognized in," Darren Walker, the president of the Ford Foundation, said, calling him a "creative genius." https://t.co/wGX0oqYgCE https://t.co/4YYQmLStmZ
Breaking News: André Leon Talley, the fashion editor who went from the Jim Crow South to the front rows of Paris couture, has died at 73. https://t.co/zHMtn2sS7p
Breaking News: New York’s attorney general said in court papers that Donald Trump’s family business repeatedly engaged in “fraudulent or misleading” practices. https://t.co/RxlIu0Ycgp

Emily’s List announced on Tuesday that it would cut off its financial support if Senator Kyrsten Sinema continues to refuse to change the Senate’s filibuster rules to allow for passage of voting rights legislation. https://t.co/Nd4M7W3nDg

Weird Al is "absolutely thrilled" that Daniel Radcliffe will be portraying him in an upcoming biopic, saying "I have no doubt whatsoever that this is the role future generations will remember him for." https://t.co/RsGJurHba0

As Tonga struggles to clean up and reconnect with the world after a volcanic eruption set off a tsunami, the country is confronting the risk that international aid workers could bring Covid to the island nation, a virus it has so far kept out. https://t.co/EaCZhSCPIe https://t.co/u6m4s5UqaL

Detainees in an Arkansas jail who had Covid were unknowingly treated by the detention center’s doctor with ivermectin, a drug that health officials have said should not be used to treat or prevent the virus, according to a new lawsuit. https://t.co/SWKKGSDZvL
Breaking News: Microsoft agreed to buy the video game maker Activision Blizzard for $68.7 billion, its largest takeover ever and a big bet on the metaverse. https://t.co/dDofndd8yW

Ruth Bader Ginsburg made her final appearance as a lawyer before the Supreme Court in 1978. More than 40 years later, still relatively few female lawyers argue cases there, our reporter Adam Liptak writes. https://t.co/LFtKGck9Zm

In Opinion
“A slaughter of wolves is underway in Montana, Idaho and Wyoming that has no precedent in the past 100 years,” writes Thomas McNamee, an author, in a guest essay. “In all three states, even wolf pups can be killed.” https://t.co/zZFK51np4m

Charles McGee, one of the last surviving Tuskegee Airmen, died on Sunday at 102. As a fighter pilot, he flew a total of 409 combat missions in World War II and the Korean and Vietnam Wars. https://t.co/LoeBRjGoqB

The French government passed a law making proof of vaccination a requirement for restaurants, sporting events and public venues. The move comes days after President Emmanuel Macron used a vulgarity to urge the unvaccinated to get their shots. https://t.co/KN1nYTajRx
Cinnamon rolls are always a good idea. This recipe comes together in under an hour. https://t.co/fyQBcYZQvV

Two women were swept to their deaths in Peru some 6,000 miles from an undersea volcanic eruption so powerful that it churned waters halfway across the globe. But on Sunday, there was little word from Tonga, which is just 40 miles from the explosion. https://t.co/7DytdlET3f
New bicycle trails that wind through Normandy is a rewarding way to explore the sun-dappled French countryside. https://t.co/QT9IMZ0XWR
